Stem: White oak trees grow to be 24 to 30 meters tall. Their long branches are covered with leaves, and their roots reach deep into the soil to hold the tree in place. White oaks drop their leaves during the winter months. In which ecosystem would forests of white oak trees be most likely to survive?
Image/Diagram Description: Table titled 'Characteristics of Four Ecosystems' with columns: Ecosystem (1-4), Temperature, Yearly Precipitation, Soil. Ecosystem 1: Long cold winters below 0°C, short cool summers; <25 cm rain; thin topsoil, frozen ground. Ecosystem 2: Warm year-round, very hot summer; <28 cm rain; sandy rocky soil. Ecosystem 3: Cold-to-moderate winters, warm summers; 76-152 cm rain; rich deep soil. Ecosystem 4: Warm and wet year-round; 200-1000 cm rain; drains quickly, thin humus.
Choices: A) Ecosystem 1, B) Ecosystem 2, C) Ecosystem 3, D) Ecosystem 4
Scenario Justification: Presents a real organism (white oak) with specific traits and asks students to match it to an appropriate ecosystem using data. Some genuine reasoning required — not immediately obvious without analyzing the table.
SEP Justification: Students must analyze and interpret data from the table to match organism traits to ecosystem characteristics. Engages the SEP in an expected but meaningful way.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of organism-environment relationships and how traits relate to habitat conditions. Goes beyond simple recall to application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function (tree traits relate to ecosystem survival) and Cause and Effect (ecosystem conditions cause survival/failure), but students don't explicitly reason with a CCC.
Key Recommendation: Strengthen CCC engagement by asking students to explain WHY Ecosystem 3 is the best match — what cause-and-effect relationship between the oak's traits and ecosystem features supports survival?

Stem: Many types of grazing animals live in Africa. The pictures show two of these animals that have about the same size and height at the shoulder. Based on observations of the pictures of these animals, which statement describes an advantage that only one of these animals has in obtaining food?
Image/Diagram Description: Side-by-side illustrations of a Thomson's gazelle (shorter neck, curved horns, compact body) and a gerenuk (notably long neck, small head, slender body, small curved horns). Both shown in profile at similar scale.
Choices: A) Thomson's gazelle can run faster to catch food because of its body shape, B) Thomson's gazelle can use its horns to move branches, C) Gerenuk has a sharp pointed nose for detecting scent of predators, D) Gerenuk has a long neck that helps it reach high to eat from trees
Scenario Justification: Presents two real organisms with observable physical differences and asks students to connect structural differences to functional advantages. Genuine scientific reasoning about how body structures relate to food-obtaining behavior.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' based on observation of visual evidence. Students must compare structures and infer function. Expected use of practice but requires reasoning beyond recall.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of how physical traits (structure) provide advantages for survival. Students must reason about structure-function relationships, not just recall definitions.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Structure and Function — students must reason that the gerenuk's long neck (structure) provides an advantage in reaching food (function). CCC focuses student thinking meaningfully.
Key Recommendation: Good question that engages structure-function reasoning. Could be elevated by asking a follow-up: 'How might both animals survive in the same habitat without competing for the same food?' which would add Cause and Effect and deeper ecological reasoning.

Stem: Some traits of living organisms are inherited, while some behaviors must be learned. Which statement related to inherited traits or acquired traits is not correct?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Number of teeth in a shark's mouth is an inherited trait only, B) Ability of lions to use camouflage to hide in grassy fields is an inherited trait only, C) Number and type of legs a cricket has is an inherited trait only, D) Behavior of a dog guiding a blind person on a walk is an inherited trait only
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon or scenario presented. Pure conceptual question asking students to identify which trait is NOT inherited. No uncertainty — straightforward classification task.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Students are selecting a factual answer from recall — no data analysis, no argument construction, no investigation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of the distinction between inherited and learned traits. Grade-appropriate DCI but used at the recall/classification level, not for sense-making.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged. No patterns, cause/effect, or systems thinking required.
Key Recommendation: No phenomenon present. Tests classification recall only. Redesign around a scenario: provide data about a litter of puppies showing both inherited traits (fur color) and learned behaviors (tricks), then ask students to sort and explain the evidence.

Stem: Which of the following is an example of climate, NOT weather?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) A sudden thunderstorm hits the city on a hot July afternoon, B) The average snowfall in Minneapolis during December is 12 inches, C) Tomorrow's forecast predicts sunny skies with a high of 75°F, D) A cold front is expected to lower temperatures across the region next week
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon. Pure vocabulary/definition distinction between weather and climate. No uncertainty whatsoever.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Simple recall of the definition difference between weather and climate.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of the weather vs. climate distinction. Grade-appropriate but purely definitional recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged. Patterns over time is implicitly relevant (climate = long-term pattern) but not required for answering.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary recall. Redesign by providing a data table of monthly temperatures over several years for a city and asking students to identify which data represents climate vs. weather patterns, requiring actual data interpretation.

Stem: A group of students visited a park and collected leaves from many different trees in order to study them. They recorded their observations about the leaves. Which of these observations does NOT describe an inherited trait?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) The leaves vary in shape and size, B) Some leaves have holes made by insects chewing on them, C) Some leaves are smooth on one side and rough on the other, D) The colors of the leaves range from light green to dark green
Scenario Justification: Provides a minimal scenario (students observing leaves) but the scenario is just context — the actual question is still about classifying inherited vs. acquired traits. Limited uncertainty.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engagement. Students classify observations, not analyze data or construct explanations.
DCI Justification: Tests inherited vs. acquired/environmental trait distinction. Same DCI as Q3, used at recall/classification level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged explicitly. Cause and Effect is implicitly present (insects cause holes) but not required as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Redundant with Q3 — tests the same construct (inherited vs. not inherited). Replace with a question that provides data about leaf variation across different environments and asks students to explain which variations are inherited vs. environmentally caused, engaging Cause and Effect.

Stem: Some animal species, such as Arctic foxes, have a thick fur coat and a thick layer of fat underneath it. The primary role of fur and fat is most likely to —
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) help them stay afloat in water, B) help them find and catch food, C) help them keep warm in the cold, D) help them defend themselves against predators
Scenario Justification: Provides a real organism (Arctic fox) with specific traits, but the answer is obvious and requires no real figuring out. Most students already know that fur keeps animals warm.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Simple recall of the function of fur and fat. No data, no analysis, no argument.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how traits help organisms survive in environments. Grade-appropriate but used at direct recall level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function and Cause and Effect, but in a trivial way that requires no explicit CCC reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Answer is too obvious — no real reasoning required. Improve by presenting data: 'Arctic foxes have two types of fur — a thin summer coat and a thick winter coat. Given data on average temperatures across seasons, explain why this change is an advantage.' This adds data interpretation and deeper cause-and-effect reasoning.

Stem: Students fill a cart with books. The cart has a handle on each end. Which actions will make moving the cart in one direction easiest for the students?
Image/Diagram Description: Illustration showing two students on opposite ends of a wheeled cart loaded with books. Student 1 is on the left, Student 2 is on the right. Arrows indicate 'Left' and 'Right' directions. Both students are gripping handles attached to the cart.
Choices: A) Student 1 pulls left while Student 2 pulls right, B) Student 1 pulls left while Student 2 pushes left, C) Student 1 pushes right while Student 2 pushes downward, D) Student 1 pushes right while Student 2 pulls upward
Scenario Justification: Presents a concrete scenario with a diagram. Students must reason about how combining forces in the same direction is more effective. Some genuine thinking required about force direction.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Planning and Carrying Out Investigations' implicitly and 'Constructing Explanations' — students must reason about force combinations and predict outcomes. Uses the practice in an expected way.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of balanced/unbalanced forces and how combining forces in the same direction produces greater net force. Application, not just recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — the combination of force directions (cause) determines ease of movement (effect). Students must reason about what happens when forces align vs. oppose.
Key Recommendation: Solid question. Could be strengthened by asking a follow-up about what happens to the cart when forces are applied in opposite directions (connecting to balanced forces concept) or asking students to predict which scenario would make the cart NOT move.

Stem: A scientist finds the plant fossil shown. Which question can the scientist most likely answer by examining this fossil?
Image/Diagram Description: Illustration of a fern-like plant fossil imprinted in rock. Shows detailed frond/leaf pattern preserved in stone.
Choices: A) What was the average monthly rainfall in the area? B) How many animals ate this plant? C) How much oxygen was in the atmosphere? D) What was the environment like when the plant was alive?
Scenario Justification: Presents a real scientific context (scientist examining a fossil) with genuine uncertainty about what can be inferred from evidence. Students must reason about the limits and possibilities of fossil evidence.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' and 'Constructing Explanations' — students must reason about what a fossil can and cannot tell us. Requires understanding the nature of scientific evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of what fossils reveal about past environments. Goes beyond defining 'fossil' to reasoning about the informational value of fossil evidence.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (past environment caused this plant to exist) and Patterns (fossil evidence reveals patterns about past life), but not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good question that tests reasoning about scientific evidence. Could be elevated by providing multiple fossils from the same site and asking students to construct an explanation of what the environment was like, requiring them to synthesize evidence.

Stem: Two students, Rachel and Kobe, conduct an investigation of force and motion. They place a toy truck on a table. One student pushes the truck from the right and the other pushes from the left at the same time. What would most likely happen to the motion of the toy truck if Kobe used twice as much force as Rachel?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram titled 'Experiment with Toy Truck' showing a toy truck on a table with Rachel's hand on the left pushing right (arrow labeled 'Push Right') and Kobe's hand on the right pushing left (arrow labeled 'Push Left').
Choices: A) The toy truck would move towards Kobe, B) The toy truck would move towards Rachel, C) The toy truck would stay still, D) The toy truck would move up
Scenario Justification: Presents an investigation scenario with a clear diagram. Students must predict outcomes when forces are unequal. Some authentic reasoning about unbalanced forces required.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Planning and Carrying Out Investigations' — students reason about an experimental outcome. Must predict based on understanding of force relationships, not just recall.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of unbalanced forces — if one force is greater, the object moves in that direction. Application in a specific context.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Cause and Effect — unequal forces (cause) result in motion toward the stronger force (effect). Students must reason through the causal chain.
Key Recommendation: Strong question similar to the tug-of-war example. Diagnostic distractors (A reveals confusion about force direction, C reveals balanced force misconception, D is weak/absurd). Replace D with a plausible distractor like 'The truck would spin in a circle' to improve diagnostic value.

Stem: Unlike humans, otters have special flaps that close off their nostrils and ears. These flaps help otters survive in an environment that is —
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) dry, B) snowy, C) windy, D) aquatic
Scenario Justification: Presents a real organism with a specific trait but the answer is obvious. Most students know otters live in water. No real uncertainty or puzzling phenomenon.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Simple recall connecting a trait to an environment. No data, no analysis, no investigation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of how traits help organisms survive in specific environments. Grade-appropriate but trivially applied.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function (flaps help in aquatic environments) but requires no explicit CCC reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Too obvious — most students know otters are aquatic without needing to reason about the flaps. Improve by presenting an unknown animal with described traits and asking students to determine which environment it likely lives in and explain WHY those traits help, requiring actual structure-function reasoning.

Stem: A group of students makes observations about fish in a small aquarium. Which observations are about inherited traits?
Image/Diagram Description: Table titled 'Observations of Fish in an Aquarium' with 6 numbered observations: 1) Most are about 10 cm long. 2) One of the fish looks sick. 3) Eight of the fish have black stripes. 4) Some fish can squeeze through small openings between rocks. 5) The fish swim to the surface when food is held over the water. 6) Some fish have wide tail fins.
Choices: A) Observations 1, 3, and 6; B) Observations 1, 2, and 4; C) Observations 2, 3, and 5; D) Observations 2, 5, and 6
Scenario Justification: Provides a scenario (observing fish) with data, but the task is still classification of inherited vs. non-inherited traits. Some reasoning required to evaluate each observation.
SEP Justification: Students must analyze a set of observations and classify them. Touches on 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' but at a basic classification level rather than drawing conclusions.
DCI Justification: Tests inherited vs. acquired/behavioral trait distinction. Same construct as Q3 and Q5 — third time testing this. Recall-level application.
CCC Justification: No CCC explicitly engaged. Patterns could be relevant but isn't required.
Key Recommendation: Third question testing inherited vs. acquired traits (with Q3 and Q5). Redundant. The observation table is a good foundation — redesign to ask students to explain WHY observation 2 (fish looks sick) is not inherited, requiring cause-and-effect reasoning about environmental vs. genetic factors.

Stem: In a classroom discussion about genetics, the teacher explains that birds can pass various traits to their chicks. Which of the following is a trait that a chick might inherit from its bird parents?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) The ability to sing specific songs, B) The color of its feathers, C) The location of its nest, D) The friends it makes
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon. No scenario. Pure recall question about inherited traits. Zero uncertainty.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of what counts as an inherited trait.
DCI Justification: Tests the inherited trait concept again. Fourth question on this topic (Q3, Q5, Q11, Q12). Recall only.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: FOURTH question testing inherited vs. acquired traits. Severe redundancy — this construct is massively over-represented. Remove and replace with a question testing a different standard. If inheritance must be tested, require students to use evidence or data rather than recall.

Stem: A new community is being built near a coast where hurricanes are common. Which of the following would be the best design solution to protect their homes from flooding during a hurricane?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Reinforcing roofs with hurricane straps, B) Building homes on raised platforms like stilts, C) Painting houses with waterproof paint, D) Using lighter materials to build houses
Scenario Justification: Presents an engineering design context but with limited complexity. Students must select the best solution for flooding specifically. Some reasoning about solution-problem fit required.
SEP Justification: Touches on 'Designing Solutions' — students evaluate options against a specific problem. But the evaluation is surface-level; students aren't analyzing trade-offs or criteria systematically.
DCI Justification: Requires some understanding of how flooding works and why elevation helps. But the correct answer is fairly obvious without deep scientific reasoning.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (raised platform prevents flood damage) but doesn't require explicit CCC reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Distractors are reasonable but the question requires minimal science reasoning. Strengthen by adding constraints (budget, materials available) and asking students to evaluate TWO solutions and explain the trade-offs, engaging engineering design practices more authentically.

Stem: A group of students at a park used a collecting net to capture several insects. The teacher transferred the insects to small terrariums that allowed the students to observe the insects before releasing them outside. Each of the following characteristics is likely an inherited trait EXCEPT —
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) a fly's missing antenna, B) a butterfly's black-and-yellow stripes, C) a dragonfly's two sets of wings, D) a beetle's green spots
Scenario Justification: Provides a mild observational scenario but the question is again classification of inherited vs. non-inherited traits. Fifth question on this topic.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice engagement. Classification recall.
DCI Justification: Same DCI as Q3, Q5, Q11, Q12. Fifth time testing inherited traits. Pure recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: FIFTH question on inherited vs. acquired traits. Critical redundancy problem — 5 of 14 questions so far test the identical construct at the identical complexity level. Remove at least 3-4 of these and replace with questions on other Grade 3 standards.

Stem: A student claims that living in groups helps Amazon River dolphins survive. Which evidence best supports the student's claim?
Image/Diagram Description: None (uses passage text about dolphin group behaviors provided on a previous page)
Choices: A) The dolphins can see each other, B) The dolphins are able to swim faster, C) The dolphins can play with each other, D) The dolphins are able to protect each other
Scenario Justification: Uses a reading passage about dolphin group behaviors as evidence. Students must connect a claim to the best supporting evidence. Some genuine reasoning about evidence-claim relationships.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — students must select the evidence that best supports a claim. This is the actual SEP required by many NGSS standards. Used in an expected way.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of how group behaviors (protection, cooperative hunting, predator watching) support survival. Students must connect behavioral evidence to a survival claim.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (group behavior causes better survival) but not explicitly required as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Good question that engages argumentation from evidence. Could be elevated by asking students to explain WHY the selected evidence supports the claim, rather than just selecting it. Also, distractor B (swim faster) is plausible and diagnostic, but A and C are weak.

Stem: The life cycle of humans is similar to the life cycle of dolphins. Based on their life cycles, how are Amazon River dolphins and humans most alike?
Image/Diagram Description: Two life cycle diagrams side by side. Figure 1: Life Cycle of the Amazon River Dolphin showing circular progression from newborn to calf to adult. Adjacent: Human life cycle showing circular progression from newborn to child to adult. Both show three stages with arrows indicating growth progression.
Choices: A) Both change shape as they grow, B) Both are born and then grow larger, C) Both develop bodies that help them swim, D) Both live in groups for protection
Scenario Justification: Provides two life cycle diagrams for comparison. But the question asks for a very basic similarity that requires minimal analysis of the diagrams — both are born and grow larger is obvious from any life cycle.
SEP Justification: Students compare two diagrams, touching on 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data.' But the comparison is trivial — both show birth-to-adult progression. Minimal analytical demand.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of life cycle similarities across species. Grade-appropriate but applied at a very basic level. Students need only recognize that both organisms are born and grow.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (similar life cycle patterns across species) but in a trivial way. Students don't need to explicitly reason about patterns.
Key Recommendation: The diagrams provide a good foundation but the question is too easy. Improve by asking: 'Based on the life cycles, what is one important DIFFERENCE between how dolphins and humans develop?' or 'At which stage are the life cycles MOST different, and why might that be?' — requiring actual comparative analysis.

Stem: Sometimes a dolphin will be forced out of its group. Based on the passage, what is one effect of an Amazon River dolphin living without a group?
Image/Diagram Description: None (references passage from earlier pages about dolphin group behaviors)
Choices: A) The dolphin will find it easier to hunt because it's alone, B) The dolphin will not live long because there is no one to take turns watching for predators, C) The dolphin will have more food for itself, D) The dolphin will protect its young better when it's alone
Scenario Justification: Uses passage evidence to predict a consequence. Students must reason about what happens when a survival advantage (group protection) is removed. Some genuine cause-and-effect reasoning.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' and 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — students must use textual evidence to predict an outcome. Meaningful practice use.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of how group behaviors support survival to predict what happens without them. Goes beyond recall to application and inference.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Cause and Effect — removal of group (cause) leads to reduced survival (effect). Students must reason through the causal chain explicitly.
Key Recommendation: Good question that requires causal reasoning with textual evidence. Distractors A and C test whether students understand that apparent benefits of being alone are outweighed by survival costs. This is one of the stronger items on the test.

Stem: Jacob investigated the strength of magnets by playing with magnetic train cars. He slid two cars toward each other. He tried different combinations of train cars. Which statement best explains the pattern in Jacob's observations?
Image/Diagram Description: Table with 4 trials showing magnetic train car setups and observations. Each trial shows two train cars with poles labeled S and N. Key shows dark cars = strong magnets, light cars = weak magnets. Trial 1: Strong(S-N) facing Strong(N-S) — got very close together. Trial 2: Strong(S-N) facing Weak(N-S) — did get close together. Trial 3: Weak(S-N) facing Strong(N-S) — did get close together. Trial 4: Weak(S-N) facing Weak(N-S) — stayed far apart.
Choices: A) Two strong magnets will have strong attractive force when same poles face each other, B) Two strong magnets will push away with great force when same poles face each other, C) Two weak magnets will push away with great force when same poles face each other, D) One strong and one weak magnet will have strong attractive force when same poles face each other
Scenario Justification: Presents an investigation with actual data in a table. Students must identify a pattern from observations and select the best explanation. Genuine data-driven reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students must read the data table, identify the pattern across trials, and select the explanation that matches. Meaningful practice use.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of magnetic forces (like poles repel, strength varies). Students must connect observations to magnet strength concepts.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Patterns — students must identify the pattern across four trials linking magnet strength to observed force. Also engages Cause and Effect (magnet strength causes different force outcomes).
Key Recommendation: One of the strongest questions on the test. Real data, pattern identification, and explanation. Could be elevated by asking students to predict what would happen in a Trial 5 with a new combination, requiring transfer of the identified pattern.

Stem: Part A: Yasmin has a desk in a corner of her bedroom. She often loses items behind her desk. Yasmin's grabber tool has been very useful for picking up fallen books, her watch, and occasionally her smartphone. The current design does not allow it to pick up very small steel tacks and paper clips. Which statement best describes the problem with the design of the grabber tool that Yasmin needs to solve?
Image/Diagram Description: Illustration of a grabber tool — a mechanical reaching device with a squeeze handle on one end and grabbing jaws/pincers on the other end, shown being held by a hand.
Choices: A) The grabber tool cannot grab and move a heavy desk, B) The grabber tool cannot pick up very small objects, C) The grabber tool cannot pick up objects without breaking them, D) The grabber tool cannot grab and move large objects
Scenario Justification: Presents an engineering design scenario but the problem identification is straightforward — the text literally states the tool can't pick up small steel tacks and paper clips. No real puzzling required.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Defining Problems' — an engineering practice. But the problem is stated explicitly in the text; students are selecting a restatement rather than identifying the problem themselves.
DCI Justification: Minimal science content required. Understanding that small objects require different gripping mechanisms is common sense, not grade-level DCI application.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged meaningfully.
Key Recommendation: The problem is stated too explicitly in the stem — students just need to match the restatement. Improve by describing ONLY what the tool can and cannot pick up (without explaining why) and asking students to identify the design limitation. This would require actual analysis rather than reading comprehension.

Stem: Part B: Which change to the grabber tool would best help Yasmin solve the design problem in Part A?
Image/Diagram Description: Same grabber tool illustration as Q19.
Choices: A) Making the handle longer, B) Making the grabbing area larger, C) Adding magnets to the grabbing area, D) Adding soft padding to the grabbing area
Scenario Justification: Builds on Part A with a genuine design challenge. Students must connect the problem (small steel objects) to a solution (magnets attract steel). Requires reasoning about material properties and magnetic forces.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — students evaluate design modifications against the specific problem. Must consider which modification addresses the actual constraint (steel objects are small AND magnetic).
DCI Justification: Requires connecting knowledge of magnets (attract steel) to the engineering problem. Students must reason that steel tacks/paper clips are magnetic, so adding magnets solves the problem. Meaningful DCI application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (adding magnets causes steel objects to be attracted) and Structure and Function (magnet structure enables picking up steel). Not explicitly required.
Key Recommendation: Good engineering design question that connects magnetic properties to a practical solution. Distractors are plausible and diagnostic (B: bigger area sounds logical but doesn't help with tiny objects; D: padding doesn't help with steel specifically). One of the better items.

Stem: The table shows information about four cities. Which city is most likely to have a blizzard in winter?
Image/Diagram Description: Table with 4 cities (W, X, Y, Z) and 3 columns: 'Does the city have temperatures below freezing for most of the winter?' (W: yes, X: no, Y: no, Z: yes), 'Does the city have strong winds during the year?' (W: no, X: no, Y: no, Z: yes), 'Usual amount of winter snowfall (centimeters)' (W: 8, X: 25, Y: 15, Z: 51).
Choices: A) city W, B) city X, C) city Y, D) city Z
Scenario Justification: Provides a data table about weather characteristics of four cities. Students must connect the definition of a blizzard (from earlier passage: strong winds + snow) to the data to identify the best match. Data-driven reasoning.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — students must read a multi-variable table and synthesize criteria (below-freezing temps + strong winds + high snowfall) to select the correct city.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what conditions cause blizzards. Requires recall of the blizzard definition from the passage and matching to data. Moderate DCI demand.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (identifying which city matches the blizzard pattern) and Cause and Effect (weather conditions cause blizzards) implicitly but not explicitly.
Key Recommendation: Decent data interpretation question. The multi-variable table is good. Could be elevated by asking students to explain WHY City Z is most likely (requiring them to articulate the evidence) rather than just selecting it.

Stem: Use the information in Table 1 to answer the question. In which state is it most important for people to prepare for winter storms?
Image/Diagram Description: Pictograph titled 'Table 1. Usual Number of Winter Storms per Year' showing snowflake icons for each state. Maine: 4 snowflakes, Missouri: 3 snowflakes, New Mexico: 1 snowflake, North Dakota: none shown clearly. Key: one snowflake = one winter storm. (Note: Based on answer key, Maine with most storms is correct.)
Choices: A) Maine, B) Missouri, C) New Mexico, D) North Dakota
Scenario Justification: Simple pictograph reading. Students count snowflake icons to determine which state has the most storms. Minimal scientific reasoning required — primarily a graph-reading skill.
SEP Justification: Reading a pictograph touches on 'Analyzing Data' but at the most basic mechanical level — counting icons. No interpretation or sense-making required.
DCI Justification: Minimal science content. Knowing that more storms = more preparation needed is common sense, not a science concept.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged. Patterns (more storms = more danger) is trivially implicit.
Key Recommendation: Pure graph-reading exercise with no science reasoning. Improve by asking: 'North Dakota gets very cold but has fewer winter storms than Maine. Using what you know about weather, explain why a state with cold temperatures might still have fewer storms.' This would require reasoning about weather patterns rather than just counting.

Stem: Which of the following describes how the thick fur of a polar bear is an adaptation?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) It is white, B) It is the thickest fur of all animals, C) It keeps them warm in their cold arctic habitat, D) It gets soaked when they swim in the water
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon. No scenario. Pure recall question about what makes something an adaptation. Nearly identical construct to Q6 (Arctic fox fur).
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Direct recall of the definition of adaptation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of adaptations. Same construct as Q6 but with a polar bear instead of Arctic fox. Recall only.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Redundant with Q6 — both test 'fur keeps animals warm in cold environments.' Remove one. If adaptation must be assessed, present an unfamiliar organism with unusual traits and ask students to explain HOW the trait helps it survive, requiring actual reasoning.

Stem: The temperature outside right now is 19°C. What is the temperature on the Fahrenheit scale?
Image/Diagram Description: Illustration of a dual-scale thermometer showing both Fahrenheit (left side, ranging from -60°F to 120°F) and Celsius (right side, ranging from -50°C to 50°C). The mercury/red line is at approximately 19°C / 65°F.
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon. No science scenario. A measurement tool reading task. Zero scientific uncertainty.
SEP Justification: Reading a thermometer is the most basic mechanical skill. No sense-making, no analysis, no investigation. Below grade-level practice demand.
DCI Justification: No science concept being tested. This is a measurement/reading skill, not a disciplinary core idea.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure tool-reading skill with no science reasoning. This belongs in a math measurement unit, not a science assessment. Remove entirely and replace with a science question. If temperature must be assessed, embed it in a weather data analysis task.

Stem: Sally has two bar magnets. She puts the end marked 'N' of one magnet close to the end marked 'N' of the other magnet. What will happen to the two magnets?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) The magnets will attract each other, B) The magnets will not have any effect on each other, C) The magnets will repel each other, D) The magnets will stick together at the middle
Scenario Justification: Simple prediction scenario but with no uncertainty — students who know the rule (like poles repel) can answer instantly. No puzzling phenomenon.
SEP Justification: No practice beyond recall. Students apply a memorized rule (like poles repel). No investigation, no data, no explanation required.
DCI Justification: Tests the rule that like magnetic poles repel. Grade-appropriate DCI but applied at pure recall level.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (like poles cause repulsion) but in a trivial, routine way.
Key Recommendation: Pure rule recall. Q18 already tested magnets with much higher complexity using actual data. This question adds no assessment value. Remove and replace with a question on a different standard, or combine with Q18 as a multi-part item.

Stem: Every year, students in Maine experience very cold winters with a lot of snow, and warm summers with occasional rain. If a student writes a report about this, they are most likely writing about Maine's:
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Daily weather, B) Atmospheric pressure, C) Climate, D) Temperature
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon. Pure vocabulary recall — identical construct to Q4 (weather vs. climate distinction).
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Definition recall.
DCI Justification: Same DCI as Q4. Second time testing weather vs. climate. Pure recall.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Exact duplicate construct of Q4. Both test weather vs. climate at the definition level. Remove one. If both must exist, at least one should require students to analyze actual data to distinguish weather from climate.

Stem: A toy car is being moved by a magnet underneath the table. The car moves wherever the magnet goes without touching the car directly. What force is the magnet applying on the toy car?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Push, B) Pull, C) Gravity, D) Friction
Scenario Justification: Simple scenario but no real uncertainty. Students who know magnets attract (pull) can answer immediately.
SEP Justification: No practice engaged. Vocabulary-level identification of force type.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic force as a non-contact pull force. Grade-appropriate but recall-level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged meaningfully.
Key Recommendation: Third magnet question (Q18, Q25, Q27) and the simplest of the three. Tests vocabulary (pull vs. push) not understanding. Remove — Q18 already covers magnets at a much higher level.

Stem: You have two balloons, a red one and a green one. You rub the red balloon on your hair, it picks up extra electrons and starts sticking to the wall. The green balloon is just blown up and not rubbed on anything and doesn't stick. What can you say about the charges on the red balloon and the green balloon?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) Red is neutral and green is positively charged, B) Red is negatively charged and green is neutral, C) Both are positively charged and will attract each other, D) Red is positively charged and green is negatively charged
Scenario Justification: Presents a concrete scenario with observable phenomena (balloon sticking to wall after rubbing on hair). Students must reason about static electricity and charge transfer. Some genuine scientific reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students must construct an explanation connecting the observation (rubbing transfers electrons, balloon sticks) to the conclusion (red is negative, green is neutral). Engages explanation from evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of static electricity, electron transfer, and charge. Students must connect 'picks up extra electrons' to 'negatively charged' and 'not rubbed' to 'neutral.' Application of DCI.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (rubbing causes charge transfer, charge causes sticking) but CCC is not explicitly required as a reasoning tool.
Key Recommendation: Good question that requires connecting a physical process to a concept. The stem provides the mechanism (picks up electrons) which scaffolds the answer significantly. Could be elevated by describing only the observations (rubbing, sticking) and asking students to explain WHY, requiring them to generate the mechanism.

Stem: The diagram shows a desert food chain. The producers in this food chain are the —
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram of a desert food chain showing: Sun (circle, top left) with arrow to Desert plants (cacti and desert vegetation) with arrow to Insects (fly illustration) with arrow to Lizards (lizard illustration) with arrow to Desert foxes (fox illustration). Label: 'Not drawn to scale.'
Choices: A) insects, B) lizards, C) desert foxes, D) desert plants
Scenario Justification: No phenomenon. No uncertainty. Vocabulary question — 'producer' is defined as the organism that makes its own food (plants). Students identify the term from a diagram.
SEP Justification: Reading a food chain diagram is mechanical skill. No analysis beyond identifying which organism is the producer. Below grade-level practice demand.
DCI Justification: Tests vocabulary knowledge of 'producer' in an ecosystem. Grade-appropriate term but used at pure recall/identification level.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged. Energy flow is implicitly present but not required for answering.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary recall from a diagram. Improve by asking: 'If the insects were removed from this food chain, what would most likely happen to the lizard and desert plant populations? Explain why.' This requires cause-and-effect reasoning about ecosystem relationships.

Stem: A group of forest mice all belong to the same species, but their fur colors are slightly different. Some have light brown fur and some have dark brown fur. A scientist releases 20 mice of each type into a forest with dark tree trunks and returns after a few weeks to count how many are still alive. The scientist wants to explain how fur color might affect the mice's chances of surviving. Which explanation BEST uses the evidence in the table?
Image/Diagram Description: Data table with columns: Fur Color, Number Released, Number Still Alive. Light brown: 20 released, 6 alive. Dark brown: 20 released, 15 alive.
Choices: A) Light brown mice survive better because their fur is different from the trees so they are easier for predators to see, B) Dark brown mice survive better because their fur blends in with dark trees so predators have harder time seeing them, C) Dark brown mice survive better because they are a different species that predators do not like to eat, D) Light brown mice survive better because there were fewer of them to start with so predators caught fewer
Scenario Justification: Presents a genuine scientific investigation with real data. Students must use evidence from a data table to evaluate competing explanations about natural selection/camouflage. Rich scenario with authentic uncertainty — multiple explanations are offered and students must select the one best supported by evidence.
SEP Justification: Strongly engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' and 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data.' Students must evaluate multiple explanations against quantitative data. This is authentic scientific reasoning — evaluating claims with evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires applying understanding of how traits (fur color) affect survival through camouflage. Connects variation, environment, and predation. Goes beyond recall to reasoning with the DCI.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (fur color affects visibility, which affects predation, which affects survival) and Patterns (pattern in survival data between light and dark mice). CCC focuses student thinking on the causal mechanism.
Key Recommendation: Strongest question on the entire test. Real data, genuine scientific reasoning, excellent distractors that test specific misconceptions (C: different species fallacy; D: mathematical misunderstanding; A: reverses the conclusion). This should serve as a MODEL for redesigning weaker questions on this assessment.
